awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Smart Data Gateway for Intelligent Transportation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of a field-testing regimen and a long-term, on-site health monitor for highway structures. This technology seeks to develop a smart and secured data gateway to integrate the data from emerging, heterogeneous cyberphysical systems and provide a seamless dashboard for transportation officials to make quick and informed actions. As a service, this technology could provide real-time traffic information such as vehicle counts, vehicle/pedestrian/wildlife classifications, and a combination of strategic alliances with private transportation agencies that are contracted to create safe traffic intersections and roundabouts. The proposed technology could also scale existing software to provide analytics such as bike and pedestrian detection, near misses, real-time asset monitoring, and the ability to provide computer-based modeling.

This I-Corps project is based on the potential development of a robust, yet adaptive smart data gateway to monitor the health of highway infrastructture.  The gateway must be capable of supporting the diverse data formats used in heterogeneous cyberphysical systems. The ability to connect  nearby cyberphysical systems to historical data in each location is challenging; The smart data gateway should connect and continuously stream data between the heterogeneous cyberphysical systems. In addition, the gateway should process the incoming data in real-time, detect the correct data format, check for any malicious data points, process the data using artificial intelligence (AI) models to prioritize the data, derive patterns, display the relevant data in the dashboard, and relay proper responses to the corresponding systems.  As a service, this technology could provide real-time traffic information to create safer traffic intersections and roundabouts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Through the National Science Foundation (NSF) Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Teams, the University of Cincinnati Infrastructure Institute (UCII), participating under a team name Yokit, has interviewed more than 200 stakeholders in the transportation ecosystem. Particularly, the team has explored several state and city departments of transportation (DOTs) to learn about their prioritized needs and wants with respect to utilizing technologies such as intelligent transportation systems (ITS) in developing and operating a safer, more efficient transportation network. The team has continued the customer discovery process after the 7-week cohort by meeting experts at several national and international conferences between 2023 - 2024. Furthermore, the team has continued to engage in extensive interview process in-person and remote to formulate the ecosystem map, highlight the challenges and opportunities at federal, state, and city jurisdictions.

Through the ODOT Student Transportation Advancement Research (STAR) program, the Yokit team explored the CAVe-In-A-Box tool and engaged young learners in 5-12 grade level students and technical experts in the transportation ecosystem. Leveraging the knowledge acquired through the NSF I-Corps program, ODOT STAR project, and collaborating with agencies such as DriveOhio on workforce development programs, the UCII team aims to make significant contributions in the development and practical application of such ITS technologies. As we move forward to make an impact on the ITS ecosystem, we will continue the customer discovery process while testing a proof of concept at UC main campus. The team has successfully received permissions from UC Parking, Public Safety, Planning teams to install a permanent camera to monitor traffic and conduct data analysis on data collected in real-world test site. The test site will also have potential to deploy the CAVe-In-A-Box tool to test and demonstrate the advantages of smart mobility to road users. We are actively making progress to partner with community organizations, traffic agencies, technology suppliers, and advocacy groups to apply for grants and pilot our technology.

Specific project outcomes include:

  • Detailed smart mobility ecosystem highlighting data providers and consumers
  • A list of challenges validated by transportation stakeholders as highlighted in the final report
  • A prototype and test site to demonstrate the smart data gateway idea and collect real world data

Last Modified: 05/02/2024
Modified by: Arthur J Helmicki
